Antinuclear Movement, 1950s-1960s - NUCLEAR NEW YORK                             NUCLEAR NEW YORK   Search this site          Home                       Home  Timeline  Invention of the Nuclear Bomb  J. Robert Oppenheimer  The Manhattan Project  Research at Columbia University   Espionage  Soviet Spies in New York  Greenglass and Rosenberg   Civil Defense and Propaganda  Public Events  1948 Atomic Energy Exhibits  1952 Civil Defense Exhibit  Preparedness Events in Harlem  Civil Defense Research  Civil Defense in New York  "Operation Alert" Drills  Protecting the City   Military Defense  Antinuclear Movement, 1950s-1960s  SANE, the Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy  Protest  SANE's First Event  Hiroshima Days  Easter Marches  Madison Square Garden Rally  Anti-Civil Defense Drill Protests  Women Strike for Peace  Communism  Nuclear Freeze Campaign, 1970s-1980s  Nuclear Power  Nuclear Power Plant in Queens  Indian Point  A Nuclear-Free Harbor, 1980s-1990s  New York Nuclear Imagery  Bibliography  About                  Antinuclear Movement, 1950s-1960s                   After the United States detonated two nuclear bombs over Japan in 1945, two strands of antinuclear activists emerged. In addition to traditional pacifists like Quakers, atomic scientists and pro-world government advocates each advocated for an end to the use of nuclear weapons. But towards the end of the decade, both groups lost momentum as ordinary people became more interested in the possibilities of nuclear energy and the idea that the US could use its nuclear weapons as a deterrent.    Truman’s Loyalty Order of 1947 made federally employed scientists afraid of being labeled Communists. The United World Federalists were plagued by financial problems and chased out of existence by McCarthyism. 46  But in 1957, widely respected humanitarian Albert Schweitzer gave a speech condemning atomic bombs, a Congressional Subcommittee on Radiation of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy held hearings that brought the issue of radioactive fallout to the public’s attention, and 2,000 scientists signed a petition that demanded an international agreement to end nuclear testing. The time seemed right for a new antinuclear movement. 47        46. Milton Katz, Ban the Bomb: A History of SANE, the Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, 1957-1985  (New York: Greenwood Press, 1986), 2, 9-11; Lawrence S. Wittner, One World or None: A History of the World Nuclear Disarmament Movement Through 1953 (Stanford, CA: Stanford University Press, 1993), 325-327. 47.  Katz, Ban the Bomb , 16-18.
